feed.title: Rasmussen Lab
feed.subtitle: Homepage of the Rasmussen Lab at UW.

entry.title: Fly/Fish ensheathment paper online at *eLife*
entry.content:
Our collaborative paper on morphological and functional coupling of skin and somatosensory neurons is now online at @elife! @marcifrosenberg made major contributions to the #zebrafish experiments. #undergraduateresearch @UWBiology @UclaMcdb https://t.co/B7M99FZckM

— Jeff Rasmussen (@jraslab) March 12, 2019

entry.title: 2019 NICHD Networking Workshop
entry.content:
Jeff just returned from the 2019 NICHD Career Planning and Networking Workshop. The workshop featured a veritable Who’s Who of Developmental Biology. Cliff Tabin spoke on signals and forces involved in chick intestinal smooth muscle morphogenesis. Marnie Halpern presented her lab’s work on left-right asymmetries in zebrafish brain development and function. Michael Barresi shared his lab’s work on morphogenesis and colonization of the CNS in zebrafish. Irene Zohn spoke on how she is using mouse genetics to understand human neural tube birth defects. A combination of short talks and “elevator talks” from trainees highlighted the future of Developmental Biology research. Thanks to the organizers for putting together this fantastic meeting!

Enlightening talk by Dr. Roshni Rao about #networking in science at the #NICHD career workshop. As an natural introvert, I appreciated her #seinfeld quote that most Americans are “Better off in the casket than doing the eulogy.”

— Jeff Rasmussen (@jraslab) March 7, 2019
entry.summary: Jeff just returned from the 2019 NICHD Career Planning and Networking Workshop. The workshop featured a veritable Who’s Who of Developmental Biology. Cliff Tabin spoke on signals and forces involved in chick intestinal smooth muscle morphogenesis. Marnie Halpern presented her lab’s work on left-right asymmetries in zebrafish brain development and function. Michael Barresi shared his lab’s work on morphogenesis and colonization of the CNS in zebrafish. Irene Zohn spoke on how she is using mouse genetics to understand human neural tube birth defects. A combination of short talks and “elevator talks” from trainees highlighted the future of Developmental Biology research. Thanks to the organizers for putting together this fantastic meeting!

entry.title: A team of undergraduates join the lab!

link.title: A team of undergraduates join the lab!

entry.content:
A team of UW undergraduates has joined the lab starting Winter 2019!

  • Christine will be working on establishing a bioinformatics pipelines for RNAseq data analysis of skin-neuron interactions.
  • Elgene will be creating tools to analyze the expression pattern of candidate axon guidance genes.
  • Ethan will be studying the development and function of macrophages in the skin.
entry.summary: A team of UW undergraduates has joined the lab starting Winter 2019!

entry.title: Emma joins the lab as 1st member!

link.title: Emma joins the lab as 1st member!

entry.content: Emma Horton has joined the lab as our brave first member! Emma is a recent UW grad, where she worked in Merrill Hille’s lab as an undergraduate researcher. In addition to helping the lab get off the ground, Emma will be working on mechanisms of skin patterning in juvenile zebrafish.
entry.summary: Emma Horton has joined the lab as our brave first member! Emma is a recent UW grad, where she worked in Merrill Hille’s lab as an undergraduate researcher. In addition to helping the lab get off the ground, Emma will be working on mechanisms of skin patterning in juvenile zebrafish.

entry.title: Post for the Node is online

link.title: Post for the Node is online

entry.content:
In a post for the Node, Jeff shares how his research career and recent paper in Developmental Cell were shaped by the generosity of fellow scientists in Los Angeles.

Read it here: Scaling the Fish: An L.A. Story.
entry.summary: In a post for the Node, Jeff shares how his research career and recent paper in Developmental Cell were shaped by the generosity of fellow scientists in Los Angeles.

entry.title: Fly/Fish skin-neurite ensheathment preprint posted
entry.content:
I am excited that our collaborative #drosophila #zebrafish paper from the Parrish and Sagasti labs is now online at #bioRxiv. Featuring the #undergraduateresearch of @marcifrosenberg from @UclaMcdb! @UWBiology https://t.co/aNzg9sz8t0

— Jeff Rasmussen (@jraslab) October 8, 2018

entry.title: Highlight in Dev Cell
entry.content: An excellent preview of our Dev cell paper from Stephanie McMillan and Marie-Andrée Akimenko is online. Read it here Scales Radi(i)cally Remodel Sensory Axons and Vasculature.
entry.summary: An excellent preview of our Dev cell paper from Stephanie McMillan and Marie-Andrée Akimenko is online. Read it here Scales Radi(i)cally Remodel Sensory Axons and Vasculature.

entry.title: #2018SDB
entry.content:
Jeff’s research was recognized with the Hilde Mangold Postdoctoral Presentation Award at the 77th Annual SDB Meeting in Portland, OR. The award was generously sponsored by Developmental Dynamics and Chroma.

Thanks to the organizers for putting together a fantastic meeting. The quality of the science was outstanding and SDB has done a great job of fostering the dev bio community! The lab looks forward to participating in many future SDB meetings.
entry.summary: Jeff’s research was recognized with the Hilde Mangold Postdoctoral Presentation Award at the 77th Annual SDB Meeting in Portland, OR. The award was generously sponsored by Developmental Dynamics and Chroma.

entry.title: R00 grant approved
entry.content: Jeff’s R00 transition application was just approved by NICHD! This award will provide funding for the first three years of research in the lab.
entry.summary: Jeff’s R00 transition application was just approved by NICHD! This award will provide funding for the first three years of research in the lab.

entry.title: Fish scale paper online at *Dev Cell*!

link.title: Fish scale paper online at *Dev Cell*!

entry.content:
Our paper on how zebrafish scales pattern skin sensory innervation and vascularization is now online at Developmental Cell. The print version is scheduled for the August 6th issue.

Many thanks to the generous zebrafish labs whose shared reagents made this study possible!
entry.summary: Our paper on how zebrafish scales pattern skin sensory innervation and vascularization is now online at Developmental Cell. The print version is scheduled for the August 6th issue.
